sushy/resources/manager/virtual_media.py.message: For the record, I don't believe this can be backported as we're changing overall default behavior. The consumers of the library would need to be aware and adjust, that is unless they already operate/interact properly.

We probably could, given how minor it is (and how unlikely it is that we have any consumers other than ironic). But the backportable version of this change is actually https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/sushy/+/802690, this one is a clean up for master only.

Julia, Dmitry - thank you for your comments.

Richard - thank you for your insights, here are some thoughts:

re 1&2 - all makes sense to me
re 3: I do not understand the purpose of Inserted either. Based on partial information I have it does feel like a leftover from previous implementations that didn't have InsertMedia call (and relied on PATCHing vMedia attributes instead, including setting Inserted?). I haven't seen a machine doing this though.

re 4: I don't understand why's that either. I had a brief chat to Dmitry and it seems like it may have been a mistake, but not sure. If other reviewers know please share!

re 5: correct

I think the code you proposed may be a superior way of achieving what I did in  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/sushy/+/802690/4/sushy/resources/manager/virtual_media.py#105 - IIUC it should produce identical results but it is more readable and elegant than my "backportable" patch.

However going forward I do see value in going the path proposed in this change. Reason being if we abandon the Ironic change and implement your suggestion, we'll have Ironic passing unnecessary/RF-default values (True, True) to insert_media(image, inserted=True, write_protected=False) (which seems to have the wrong default for write_protected) which then drops inserted and write_protected which were never needed in the first place and only passes the image to the BMC. It will work but seems convoluted and hard to follow. I guess legacy brought us to this but from my perspective it is tempting to clear this out if possible at reasonable level of effort/risk. So - my proposal:

* replace the code in the "backportable" change (link above) with your proposal, go ahead with this and backport as required
* still go ahead with this change and Ironic change but make them master only.

What do you think?

I am wondering if the existing default values of the optional arguments inserted and write_protected need to be changed at all. First, several observations:

1. Both are used to convey optional parameters to the Redfish InsertMedia action, Inserted and WriteProtected.
2. When a client does not provide those optional parameters, the BMC Redfish "service shall default this value to be true." [1] That has been the case since the VirtualMedia schema introduced the InsertMedia action [2].
3. They seem to be orthogonal. (I also do not understand the purpose of Inserted.)
4. I do not understand why the default value of write_protected is False. Does anyone have any insights on that?
5. Ironic has been calling this method with both explicitly set to True.

If the existing default values were left as-is, the logic below could be changed to add the optional parameters only if they evaluate to False.

    payload = {
        'Image': image
    }
    if not inserted:
        payload['Inserted'] = False
    if not write_protected:
        payload['WriteProtected'] = False

It seems to me this approach would eliminate the need for a backportable version and the  related ironic change [3].

Caveat: AfAIK, this has not been tested against the iDRAC, yet.

[1] https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/VirtualMedia.v1_4_0.json
[2] https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/VirtualMedia.v1_2_0.json
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic/+/802643

Would not this encounter the issue being addressed when the caller passes True for either of the optional arguments?

    insert_media, image, inserted=True, write_protected=True)

You are right Richard, this would still cause failures on SuperMicro X11/X12. However if this change and Ironic change merge, Ironic will never send these and hence insert_media will default to None for Inserted and WriteProtected and will not include them in the payload, leaving it to the BMC to set the Redfish-specified defaults. Does this make sense?

I understand the related ironic change and its interaction with this one. My concern is that the default values of inserted and write_protected and processing of them proposed here would continue to make it easy for consumers of sushy to unknowingly set themselves up to trip over the failure; just pass True. I suggest we make it more challenging.

AFAIU, among sushy's goals is to encapsulate accommodations for BMC Redfish service implementations which make them sing. That said, it would be nice to offer the flexibility to send true for those optional Redfish payload parameters should they be needed for development work or other reasons. How about this?

    def insert_media(self, image, inserted=None, write_protected=None, send_true=False)

Also, I suggest the docstring mention the interoperability risk of passing True for those parameters.
could add here to say that default is True for systems that support PATCH, if end-users will be able to make decision what they need..
Done. Do you think the way I phrased it is clear enough? Thank you.

I have a few concerns I'd like us to consider before merging :
- who and how someone could propose a change for being prioritized ?
- when and how the nova-cores are going to accept a change to be a priority ?

Depending on the outcome of those two questions, then we would see what kind of votes we should use.

For the moment, I'd prefer we debate over the process itself rather than on the implementation directly.

i feel like that is far to much process an paper work

we coudl do that but i feell its overkill.

cahnge owner adding +1 i can get behind with cores adding +2 to accept it.

when a core adds a +2 we can arguable but the act of a core adding a +2 i think comes with an implict statement that i (core added +2) am willing to reivew this and would like other to also.

so i think that woudl make it inherntly self limiting as cores are not going to want to over subscibe them selves.


we could use a +3 to signel accpeate if we wanted too or just a +2 since its at least a review priorty for a core but that could also be achive with cores setting +1 and the PTL or cores setting +2 when there is enough concensus.
that could be acive by 3 in cores in your case agreeing its a priorty by +1ing it or in a meeting.

be the intent of this propsal was something very light wight to give us  a quick way to order the open reviews.

if we put too much process around it i feel like we wont use it.

My experience from the runways was twofold:
1) it only worked if there was somebody keeping the etherpad up to date
2) it was as effective as we kept it honest and did the reviews on the items in the slots.

So I don't want to create another process that needs a central authority that accepts things. Instead I would like to trust cores that when they mark something as priority then they also themselves commit to review the patch.

I also think that if a core reviewed a patch then that core should easily find another core as a second reviewer if needed.

I think the raise-attention-to-a-patch-by-the-owner does not need to be automated in gerrit by this new flag. We have already a bunch of ways to raise attention. It can be brought up on IRC, ML, or even on the weekly meeting, and cores can be added to the review by the author. We can keep these as is. 

bottom line I propose the following:

* have a 0, +1 flag that can only set by the members of the core team
* a core set the priority flag to +1 to indicate that he/she help the author to get the patch merged. 
* I expect that the cores will limit the number of patches marked with +1 based on their review bandwidth
* I expect that cores will check the list of reviews having +1 by other cores before they mark a new one to see where they can help first by being the second core for the patch. (Note two cores can independently vote +1)
* I will add an agenda point to the weekly meeting where we quickly look at the overall list of patches with +1 mark to keep a horizontal view what is happening in nova.

@Sean: can we configure gerrit that this +1 is not automatically reset when a new revision is pushed?

OK, I see your concern, gibi.
My only take is that I wonder how to help the contributors by asking us to look at their changes.
If not, I'm not sure we would need to have this new label as we already discuss in between us in the IRC channel for asking to review.
written up my proposal to the contributor doc https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/792357

My personal take on the above is that :
- contributors could propose a change to be prioritised asynchrounsly (maybe be using Gerrit, but at least not by being in a meeting)
- nova cores should accept a change by voting asynchronously (maybe by Gerrit as well)
- the result of the votes could be at some deadline (like in a meeting)

A strawman proposal could be :
- contributors tag on Gerrit their changes by flagging Review-Priority to be +1
- cores have until next meeting to vote on open changes that are proposed whether they accept them as priority or not by tagging the Review-Priority level to be +2
- at the meeting, the PTL will look over the number of +2s and if 3 cores voted +2, the PTL does set a new Gerrit label like "Review Priority Accepted"

This way, we would know whose cores expressed interest in reviewing such change, actually being honest about saying "OK, I take the point that I'd like to review this change"
based on my understanding copyAnyScore is enough as min/max is subset of any
this seems OK as we have no negative value for this flag, but I think NoBlock/NoOp would communicate our intentions better.
These two options should not be necessary with copyAnyScore below. To prevent future cargo culting of unnecessary options can we clean this up?

Note that other projects seem to be using a combination of copyMinScore and copyMaxScore, which I think will be functionally equivalent when you consider the vote range/values used. I don't object, though other reviewers may be concerned about maintaining consistency of Review-Priority label definitions. This would also be the first use of copyAnyScore in our ACLs, based on the need to edit the allowed options list in the linter.
I believe copyAnyScore is a new gerrit feature and other uses are done different as they predate our upgrade.

Should use append() to add to the list
ok. i thought it was appending one entry to the list. since its concatenating two lists, '+' is fine.

I am guessing you are pointing to the single element list and why not use append() because it is only adding one element. This could have been a very simple decision to make by the author of the first armada app that was the source of inspiration to subsequent app implementations. I  think the initial author chose to use "+" instead of append() to avoid a None result of the append(). Appending an item to a list updates an existing list. It modifies the list in place instead of returning a new list. If you try to assign the result of the append() method to a variable, you encounter a “TypeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'append'” error.
See also: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/42955570/why-does-the-append-method-return-none-with-my-list
The implementation using "+" operation is a concatenation of a list to a list and not addition of an element to a list. It is used the same way in all armada apps including cert-manager.
same comment as above. Use append() for list addition

The exact same implementation was done in cert-manager armada app as well as most armada apps if not all. Function get_overrides() is called by the helm stevedore application plugin in sysinv and with the exception of an invalid namespace it will return all charts overrides that the application has. If a namespace is specified then it will return the overrides for that namespace. You can see more details about the application plugin implementation in sysinv.

Before you start on this series, what's the chances of moving these tests to their own file? This file is growing without bound and we're about to add a whole lot more stuff on top. It'll have a slight backport implication but shouldn't be too crazy

This file is huge, I totally agree. Lets move all the port resource request related tests to a separate one.

//later 

The interactive rebase of this move was interesting. As every later patch in this series modifies the part of the test_servers.py that was moved now to test_servers_resource_request.py. Git only follow file renames and moves, but not partial content move. So all those patches got in merge conflict with the new base where the content is moved away from test_servers. After some googling I ended up doing the following to avoid the manual work resolving these trivial but tiresome conflicts: 

  $ git rebase -i <before-this-patch> # with stopping at before this patch
  $ # do the partial code move and create a separate commit out of it
  # repeat until rebase finished:
    $ git rebase --continue # it stops with the next patch touching test_severs with a conflict
    $ git reset --hard HEAD  # step the interactive rebase backwards
    # download the patch file from gerrit for the conflicting patch > a.patch
    $ sed -i 's/test_servers.py/test_servers_resource_request.py/g a.patch
    $ git am .patch
  # done

NIT The the commit message should be self contained to be helpful in the future. A better commit message would be like:

Set parent share az when creating a share from snapshot

This patch-set modifies how we manage user input when creating a share from snapshot. Since we use the same form for the basic create share workflow and for the create share from snapshot workflow, we need to add a check to distinguish both cases: when creating a share from snapshot, then the parent share availability zone is picked by default. Otherwise, if it's a regular share create, the user can pick up the availability zone they need.

Closes-Bug: #1915706

We had a discussion around this before, i don't exactly remember what was decided but i remember a point regarding the default API version being 3.0 and that is what users will usually see in API response.
Although I don't have issues keeping it to the latest, it seems slightly misleading since it requires users to pass a microversion (and is not correct by default) but on the other hand users should also know which request/response are available with the latest microversion change.
Just wanted to get my thoughts on this one since we will follow the same pattern for other APIs as well.

I have a different opinion, documentation should show the latest one (iirc is also what you get in the client if you don't pin a specific microversion).

Like with features, we list them all, even if you need a specific microversion. We are also properly documenting for each parameter when they are being added, so anyone reading the documentation should see the mention of microversion and take the hint that this requires something "special".

If we decide to do it differently we'll have to update the ones from my previous patch as well [1].

We could always add both, 3.0 and latest, and clearly label them (after all we have both samples available for the tests):

  Response Example (base microversion 3.0)

  Response Example (latest microversion 3.41)

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/791239/4/api-ref/source/v3/volumes-v3-volumes.inc
I really like the idea of keeping both, but if the team agree that keeping latest is sufficient then also i don't have issues.

placement/objects/usage.py.message: Note to self: this is including the consumer_type and consumer_count key/values in the result if consumer_type=True.

I don't think we'd like to have this here, that said, this usage object is created and describes the total usages per resource class + consumer_type. We can calculate consumer count per resource class as this patch does, but what we want to return to users is not counts per resource class but total consumer counts per consumer type and that is not relevant to each resource class, right?

Thanks for adding the example. Sorry I did not follow your original concern.

I keep confusing myself with this Usage class + consumer_count. :\

Looking at it again, the consumer_count is *not* related to the resource_class -- it is a count of how many consumers are of the consumer_type. The resource_class shows the usage per resource_class. So in your example, it is option B.

I will add a code comment explaining the meaning of consumer_count.

My concern was it was not obvious from here if 

    usage(resource_class=VCPU,
          usage=10
          consumer_type=MIGRATION
          consumer_count=5)

means 

A) there are 5 consumers of MIGRATION that use VCPU and the total is 10 (i.e. this counts only consumers that use VCPU. Every consumer in the five uses at least one VCPU)

or 

B) there are 5 consumers of MIGRATION and the total usage of VCPU is 10 (there can be a consumer in the five that does not use VCPU at all)

I am good with this data structure design, but I would at least leave a comment for this. (an alternative is to get another class that includes this usage class + consumer_type + consumer_counts to make this point clearer and do counting query completely out of that "_get_by_consumer_type()").

The context for consumer types is [from my perspective] mostly about being able to count usages to enforce quota on resources. Because of this, we do want to know amount of usage for a resource class + consumer type.

Concrete example is, in nova, during a resize we want to count how much resource is being held by the pending resize (before user chooses confirm or revert). We can't do it today because we can't tell the difference between allocations of consumer type INSTANCE vs allocations of consumer type MIGRATION.

Today, without consumer types, we experience the situation where we count resources on both source and destination during a resize. So if old flavor had 2 VCPU and new flavor has 4 VCPU our quota usage shows as 6 VCPU before user chooses confirm or revert.

With consumer types, we want to use it to let quota usage reflect only the absolute value of the delta. So in the same scenario, if we know that 2 VCPU are of consumer type MIGRATION and 4 VCPU are of consumer type INSTANCE, then we can reflect quota usage as only 4 VCPU before the user chooses confirm or revert.
This should have been mentioned in the spec so it maybe too late but why did we decide to not change the `GET /usages/<rp_uud>` API as well?

Before 1.37, GET '/usages' and '/resource_providers/{uuid}/usages' had similar response format.  Therefore if one is changed in a microversion I expect the other is also changed in the same manner in the same microversion.

There isn't a 'GET /usages/<rp_uuid>' API but there is a 'GET /resource_providers/{uuid}/usages' API [1]. That is what you meant, right?

OK, looking in the next patch, I see now that we are only proposing an update to 'get_total_usages' in placement/handlers/usage.py which is the 'GET /usages' API but no change to 'list_usages' which is the 'GET /resource_providers/{uuid}/usages' API.

Many things are in play. I discovered couple of things since my last review.

A PUT /allocations/{uuid} call has two major parts. A) updating the consumer (user,project, consumer_type) and B) updating the allocation of the consumer. 

The allocations key is mandatory in the allocation update request. So allocation update is always happening. During that allocation update (Allocation.replace_all()) placement does an atomic consumer generation check in the DB. 
https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/6f00ba5f685183539d0ebf62a4741f2f6930e051/placement/objects/allocation.py#L392
https://github.com/openstack/placement/blob/6f00ba5f685183539d0ebf62a4741f2f6930e051/placement/objects/consumer.py#L229

Also both A) and B) happens in the same DB transaction which means that if the allocation update fails on consumer_generation conflict then changes made to the consumer during A) is rolled back automatically.

So we are basically safe in case of the following race:
We have a consumer with consumer_generation=0 consumer_type=INSTANCE
1) request-1 with consumer_generation=0 consumer_type=ONE reaches placement and validates consumer_generation in ensure_consumer() and updates the consumer_type in the DB in transaction
2) request-2 with consumer_generation=0 consumer_type=TWO reached placement and validates the consumer_generation successfully and updates the consumer_type in the the DB in another transaction.
3) request-1 does the allocation update successfully and bumps the consumer generation. Then commits the transaction
4) request-2 does the allocation update but fails to bump the consumer generation as #3) created a conflict. This DB transaction is rolled back and request-2 rejected with 409


So specifically to this consumer create case, if we get ConsumerExists then it means that we are req-2 and req-1 already committed the consumer creation (or we have bad transaction isolation as we see an uncommitted create). If we had the same consumer_generation as req-1 then later in the allocation update part of this request we will fail with conflict and the request gets rejected with 409.
If req-2 already knows the consumer_generation bump from req-1 and having the new generation in the request that means at L138 req-2 should also see the consumer req-1 created so we never end up in _create_consumer() in the first place.

Bottom line, assuming full db transaction separation, I think when we see ConsumerExists here then we know that the request will fail on consumer_generation conflict later in the allocation update. So it does not matter what we set as consumer_type here.

But I'm not 100% sure about DB isolation. Can one transaction see the uncommitted create of another transaction? If yes then we have a more complicated situation.

I've added some tests top of this patch. It shows that if there are two consecutive requests use that same consumer generation (e.g. two racing consumer creation from the client perspective) then during the second request the consumer type updated at L147 then the check at L150 rejects the second create, and L213 rollbacks the consumer_type to its original value. So we need the logic at L213 (or we need to move the update at L147 under L150). But this is not the racy case from the server perspective as the first request finishes before the second request arrives. I have hard time simulating the racy case as gabbit is inherently sequential. So what I do instead is that I temporary removed the check at L150 and rerun the same test. In this case the Allocation.replace_all() consumer_generation check rejects the second request. However in this case the consumer_type update is not rolled back as you correctly predicted. So I guess we need some logic higher in the call stack that handles ConcurrentUpdateDetected and rollbacks consumer_type update :/

+1 to keep unknown special to avoid db migration.

No. We only come in here are trying for 5 minutes and if priSeckeyName is empty then there is something else that is wrong and can not be resolved here. So we need to move on and have manual intervention later.

can you put some brief comments here on what "continue so that certificates that are rotated successfully are deployed" would mean to the system?  This seems to indicate not all certs are there yet, if there is no harm to simply move forward, then why all these checks and waits in the first place?

Some certificates have already been rotated successful, which means - the secrets that are mounted on pods have been updated. So if a pod restarts, it will start using new certificate which may cause problem when communicating with pods with old certificates. So we go ahead and restart the pods later to call the new certs can be deployed.

The wait is need to make sure that we are giving enough time for new certificates to be created.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/kuber.message:
I think this is a bit simplistic.  It's conceivable that we might at some point be running version 1.a.b and have several valid upgrade options, 1.a.b+1, 1.a.b+x, or 1.a+1.z and all of those should technically be shown as "available".

If we describe the version as major.minor.patch, then the available versions would be all those with the same major.minor and the patch version is greater than the current patch version, and also all those with the same major and the minor is one larger than the current minor.

In fact, it might be simplest to just use the "upgrade_from" field in the output of get_kube_versions(), and for each one where we can upgrade from the current version we can mark it as available.  That way there's one source of truth.
